segment.source: description: Lists language-level support in XAML for the Windows Runtime for certain data types in the common language runtime (CLR) and in other programming languages such as C++.
segment.target: description: Lists language-level support in XAML for the Windows Runtime for certain data types in the common language runtime (CLR) and in other programming languages such as C++.

segment.source: title: XAML intrinsic data types
segment.target: title: XAML intrinsic data types

segment.source: ms.assetid: D50E6127-395D-4E27-BAA2-2FE627F4B711
segment.target: ms.assetid: D50E6127-395D-4E27-BAA2-2FE627F4B711

segment.source: XAML intrinsic data types
segment.target: XAML intrinsic data types

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: XAML for the Windows Runtime provides language-level support for several data types that are frequently used primitives in the common language runtime (CLR) and in other programming languages such as C++.
segment.target: XAML for the Windows Runtime provides language-level support for several data types that are frequently used primitives in the common language runtime (CLR) and in other programming languages such as C++.

segment.source: The most common place you'll see XAML intrinsic data type usages is when resources are defined in a XAML resource dictionary.
segment.target: The most common place you'll see XAML intrinsic data type usages is when resources are defined in a XAML resource dictionary.

segment.source: You might define constants there, for example numbers that you use for multiple values.
segment.target: You might define constants there, for example numbers that you use for multiple values.

segment.source: Or you might use a storyboarded animation that animates using a string or Boolean value, and you'll then need a XAML object element representing the string or Boolean to fill the keyframe of your ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames definition.
segment.target: Or you might use a storyboarded animation that animates using a string or Boolean value, and you'll then need a XAML object element representing the string or Boolean to fill the keyframe of your ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames definition.

segment.source: The Windows Runtime default XAML templates use both these techniques.
segment.target: The Windows Runtime default XAML templates use both these techniques.

segment.source: XAML for the Windows Runtime provides language-level support for these types.
segment.target: XAML for the Windows Runtime provides language-level support for these types.

segment.source: | XAML primitive | Description |
segment.target: | XAML primitive | Description |

segment.source: | x:Boolean | For CLR support, corresponds to Boolean.
segment.target: | x:Boolean | For CLR support, corresponds to Boolean.

segment.source: XAML parses values for x:Boolean as case insensitive.
segment.target: XAML parses values for x:Boolean as case insensitive.

segment.source: Note that "x:Bool" is not an accepted alternative.
segment.target: Note that "x:Bool" is not an accepted alternative.

segment.source: | x:String | For CLR support, corresponds to String.
segment.target: | x:String | For CLR support, corresponds to String.

segment.source: Encoding for the string defaults to the surrounding XML encoding.
segment.target: Encoding for the string defaults to the surrounding XML encoding.

segment.source: | x:Double | For CLR support, corresponds to Double.
segment.target: | x:Double | For CLR support, corresponds to Double.

segment.source: In addition to the numeric values, text syntax for x:Double permits the token "NaN", which is how "Auto" for layout behavior can be stored as a resource value.
segment.target: In addition to the numeric values, text syntax for x:Double permits the token "NaN", which is how "Auto" for layout behavior can be stored as a resource value.

segment.source: The tokens are treated as case sensitive.
segment.target: The tokens are treated as case sensitive.

segment.source: You can use scientific notation, for example "1+E06" for .
segment.target: You can use scientific notation, for example "1+E06" for .

segment.source: | x:Int32 | For CLR support, corresponds to Int32.
segment.target: | x:Int32 | For CLR support, corresponds to Int32.

segment.source: x:Int32 is treated as signed, and you can include the minus ("-") symbol for a negative integer.
segment.target: x:Int32 is treated as signed, and you can include the minus ("-") symbol for a negative integer.

segment.source: In XAML, the absence of a sign in text syntax implies a positive signed value.
segment.target: In XAML, the absence of a sign in text syntax implies a positive signed value.

segment.source: These XAML language primitives are generally the only cases in which you define an object element that uses the x: prefix in your XAML.
segment.target: These XAML language primitives are generally the only cases in which you define an object element that uses the x: prefix in your XAML.

segment.source: All other XAML language features are typically used in attribute form, or as a markup extension.
segment.target: All other XAML language features are typically used in attribute form, or as a markup extension.

segment.source: Note By convention, the language primitives for XAML and all other XAML language elements are shown with the "x:" prefix.
segment.target: Note By convention, the language primitives for XAML and all other XAML language elements are shown with the "x:" prefix.

segment.source: This is how XAML language elements are typically used in real-world markup.
segment.target: This is how XAML language elements are typically used in real-world markup.

segment.source: This convention is followed in the documentation for XAML and also in the XAML specification.
segment.target: This convention is followed in the documentation for XAML and also in the XAML specification.

segment.source: Other XAML primitives
segment.target: Other XAML primitives

segment.source: The XAML 2009 specification notes other XAML language-level primitives such as x:Uri and x:Single.
segment.target: The XAML 2009 specification notes other XAML language-level primitives such as x:Uri and x:Single.

segment.source: Unless listed in the table in this topic, other XAML language primitives as defined by other XAML vocabularies or by the XAML 2009 specification are not currently supported in XAML for the Windows Runtime.
segment.target: Unless listed in the table in this topic, other XAML language primitives as defined by other XAML vocabularies or by the XAML 2009 specification are not currently supported in XAML for the Windows Runtime.

segment.source: Note Dates and times (properties that use DateTime or DateTimeOffset, TimeSpan or System.TimeSpan) aren't settable with a XAML primitive.
segment.target: Note Dates and times (properties that use DateTime or DateTimeOffset, TimeSpan or System.TimeSpan) aren't settable with a XAML primitive.

segment.source: These properties generally aren't settable in XAML at all, because there's no default from-string conversion behavior in the Windows Runtime XAML parser for dates and times.
segment.target: These properties generally aren't settable in XAML at all, because there's no default from-string conversion behavior in the Windows Runtime XAML parser for dates and times.

segment.source: For initialization values of any date and time properties, you'll have to use code-behind that runs when a page or element loads.
segment.target: For initialization values of any date and time properties, you'll have to use code-behind that runs when a page or element loads.
